labels.text: In this work, Hung Fai challenges the practice of ‘Transmission’ (exercises of copying and imitating) from Xie He’s‘ Six Principlesof Chinese Painting’ written in the sixth century. Hung first invited his father and acclaimed landscape painter Hung Hoi to paint a large rock, a symbol of endurance and solidity, with brush and cinnabar on paper, creating an integrated representation of classical authority; he then put two layers of paper on and underneath it, dampened them and traced the revealed cinnabar contours with a black fountain pen. As both sets of ink seeped through the paper, the steady red lines and bouncing black dots unevenly duplicated and overlapped, embodying the shifting power relations between father and son,tutor and pupil.
熊輝藉此作詰問六世紀南朝畫家謝赫所提出的「繪畫六法」中「傳移摹寫」之論。熊輝之父熊海乃知名山水畫家，藝術家邀得父親用毛筆和硃砂顏料，在紙上繪畫寓意堅定不移的磐石，反映傳統的權威。然後熊輝分別於畫作上下放置兩層紙，潤濕後以黑色墨水筆描摹穿透浮現的朱紅線條。兩層墨水滲透紙背，連貫的紅線與跳躍的墨點不時重複、重疊，象徵父子、師生之間權力關係的相互轉移。

title.en: The Six Principles of Chinese Painting - Transmission IV (with Hung Hoi)
title.zh-hant: 繪畫六法—傳移摹寫之四（熊海合作）

images.AltText: Ink and colour painting on paper divided up into five equal vertical sections, marked by faded folds along the paper. Each section has a large stencil of an illustration of a rock in red ink.
